<summary>
• PhD A, B, and C discuss the upcoming visit of Guenter Hans from the spectral subtraction group, who will be in for three weeks and contribute to the ongoing work.
  • They anticipate potential longer collaboration and his easygoing nature.
  • Guenter will review their work and provide feedback.

• Grad E presents findings on using past and present frames to calculate the mean for spectral subtraction in the SmartKom system.
  • A test with twelve seconds of speech showed a slight drop in performance when compared to a twelve-second centered window.
  • Experiments with shorter training windows (2, 4, 6, 8 seconds) showed minimal impact on word error rates.

• Discussion on the effectiveness of Wiener filtering in speech enhancement.
  • PhD B reports a 30% improvement over the baseline with a single-stage Wiener filter, which is less than the expected 40% without Wiener filtering.
  • PhD D clarifies that the baseline is the MFCC system, and the improvement is measured in word error rates.

• PhD D's experiments with Wiener filtering show a 56.46% improvement on the SpeechDat-Car dataset using ten frames of noise estimate and two-stage Wiener filtering.
  • The improvement is less than the French Telecom system but still significant.
  • The group discusses the importance of a good VAD and the potential of using channel zero VAD for noise estimation.

• PhD D explores nonlinear smoothing to reduce musical noise in spectral subtraction.
  • The smoothing is applied in both time and frequency domains, with the aim of reducing spots of high energy in silence portions of the spectrogram.
  • The group considers the possibility of using neural networks for nonlinear spectral subtraction, but acknowledges the need to define clear targets for training.
</summary>

<summary>
• Marketing and Industrial Designer discuss the functional requirements for a new remote control design.
    • The remote control will be primarily for television use, with a focus on younger users (16-45 years old) who are interested in advanced features like LCD screens and speech recognition.
    • The remote control will have a low power usage, with essential buttons like volume, channel, and power clearly visible.
    • A docking station will be used for recharging, and the remote will automatically enter standby mode after a period of inactivity.
    • The remote control will have a mute button, separate menus for teletext, screen settings, audio settings, and channel settings, and the possibility of large buttons or a touch screen.
    • The remote control will be available in different colors and possibly have adjustable fronts.
    • The remote control will have a standard on/off button, with the television turning on when the remote is activated.
    • The remote control will not have a separate button for turning the television on, but will have a menu option for selecting the television.
    • The remote control will not have a teletext function, but will have a separate menu for it.
    • The remote control will have a separate menu for different languages, and the possibility of speech recognition will be considered if budget allows.

• The sector is managing the challenges posed by Brexit, but the longer the uncertainty persists, the more difficult it becomes for institutions to plan effectively.
• The committee will discuss the Welsh Government's draft budget for the forthcoming financial year in private session.

<summary>
* Kirsty Williams AM, Cabinet Secretary for Education, values the Welsh baccalaureate for its role in providing a broad and balanced curriculum, preparing students for further study and the world of work, and its positive feedback from learners and teachers.
* * Concerns about the Welsh baccalaureate include balancing it with other qualifications, workload issues, and potential negative impact on student well-being.
* * The qualification is valued by learners at key stage 4 and post 16, with the challenge being to communicate its value and ensure consistent support from school leaders.
* * Professional learning for teachers is a key focus, with existing support from regional consortia and the WJEC, and a national approach to professional learning being developed.
* * The Welsh baccalaureate is recognized as an equivalent to A-levels by universities, with some variations in how universities use it for admissions offers.
* * The Welsh Government is working closely with Qualifications Wales to develop a joint communication plan and address concerns about the qualification's rigour and consistency in delivery.
* * The Welsh baccalaureate is expected to be universally adopted by all institutions by 2020, with flexibility for individual student circumstances.
* * The Welsh baccalaureate is not expected to narrow the curriculum but rather ensure a broad range of learning opportunities.
* * Teacher preparedness for the Welsh baccalaureate is being addressed through ITE accreditation and ongoing professional development, with new resources and support being made available.
* * The Welsh baccalaureate is supported by universities and is seen as a valuable qualification for Welsh students, with no evidence of disadvantage to Welsh students taking it.
* * The Welsh Government is committed to ensuring that all schools are in a position to deliver the Welsh baccalaureate well, with a focus on quality and consistency in delivery.
* * The Welsh baccalaureate is seen as a valuable qualification that complements traditional qualifications and prepares students for higher education and the world of work.
</summary>

<summary>
• Julie Morgan AM, Deputy Minister for Health and Social Services, discusses the Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill, emphasizing the protection of children's rights and the prohibition of all forms of physical punishment.
  • •
• Acknowledges the opposition from parents who believe in the difference between child abuse and a 'light smack' from a loving parent.
  • •
• Stresses that the Bill aims to remove any defense for common assault, not to criminalize parents, and highlights the importance of a comprehensive awareness campaign.
  • •
• Addresses concerns about the potential increase in child-on-child violence statistics post-ban in Sweden, citing a study of 88 countries showing less youth violence associated with prohibition of corporal punishment.
  • •
• Responds to the need for clarity in the law and the importance of a one-clause Bill for simplicity, while being open to considering amendments.
  • •
• Discusses the implementation of the Bill, including the establishment of an implementation group and the commitment to ongoing evaluation and monitoring.
  • •
• Reassures that social services will not be overwhelmed by the change, as they are already equipped to handle reports of physical punishment.
  • •
• Highlights the importance of multi-agency working and the existing mechanisms for joint working between social services and the police.
  • •
• Discusses the need for a mapping exercise to identify gaps in parenting support services and the potential for investment in early intervention strategies.
  • •
• Addresses the concerns of the National Association of Head Teachers regarding the funding of training and the practical implications of the Bill.
  • •
• Outlines the government's approach to human rights considerations, balancing the rights of children and parents, and the necessity of the Bill's provisions.
  • •
• Emphasizes the need for a significant awareness campaign to ensure the effectiveness of the legislation.
  • •
• Acknowledges the public's misunderstanding of the current law and the importance of clarity in the proposed legislation.
  • •
• Reiter

<summary>

    • Minister Kirsty Williams emphasized the importance of safety, well-being, and clear communication with parents and staff before any school reopening.
      • She mentioned the need for a phased return, prioritizing vulnerable children and those with additional learning needs.
      • The Minister also highlighted the importance of testing, tracing, and quarantining in the next phase of easing restrictions.
  • The committee also discussed the current situation of children and young people in schools, including the number of children attending school hubs and the challenges faced by vulnerable children.
    • The Minister acknowledged the increase in vulnerable children attending school hubs and the efforts to support them.
      • She also addressed the need for continued support for children's mental health and well-being during the pandemic.
      • The Minister discussed the Welsh Government's efforts to ensure equal access to digital learning resources for all children.
  • The committee also discussed the impact of COVID-19 on examinations and vocational qualifications, with the Minister explaining the measures taken to provide clarity and support to students.
    • She mentioned the launch of a program for year 13 students to prepare for university and the availability of resources on the Hwb platform.
      • The Minister also discussed the challenges faced by students in higher education and the ongoing discussions with universities and student unions to support them.
</summary>

<summary>
• Minister Kirsty Williams AM outlines five principles for reopening schools amid the COVID-19 pandemic.
    • Principle 1: Safety and well-being of children, young people, and staff are paramount.
    • Principle 2: Decisions must be communicated clearly to build confidence among parents, staff, and students.
    • Principle 3: Phased return, prioritizing vulnerable and additional learning needs pupils.
    • Principle 4: Operationalizing safe school settings, addressing practical challenges like social distancing and staffing.
    • Principle 5: Collaboration with education sectors, including FE and HE, to align approaches.
• Minister emphasizes that schools are not returning to normal and no immediate changes are imminent.
    • Decisions will be based on advice from medical and scientific advisers, with a focus on public health.
• Minister discusses the current operation of school hubs, including the number of children and staff attending, and the challenges of identifying vulnerable children.
    • Minister assures that local authorities are working with schools to support vulnerable children and their families.
• Minister addresses the importance of testing, tracing, and quarantining in the next phase of education.
• Minister acknowledges the mental health impact on children and the need for increased counselling services.
    • Additional funding is being made available to local authorities to support children and families during the pandemic.
• Minister discusses the Welsh Government's efforts to ensure equal access to digital learning resources.
    • Officials are working with local authorities to provide hardware and connectivity to students.
• Minister addresses concerns about the impact of the pandemic on students' education and future opportunities.
    • A-level and GCSE results will be awarded based on teacher assessments and student rankings.
    • Universities are being supported through discussions with the Higher Education Funding Council for Wales and Universities Wales.
• Minister reassures that student support payments will not change due to students returning home.
    • Ongoing dialogue with NUS Wales and other institutions is underway to support students affected by the pandemic.
• Committee agrees to meet in private for the remainder of the meeting.

<summary>
* The Children, Young People and Education Committee welcomed Jayne Bryant as a substitute for Jack Sargeant and discussed the Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Bill.
* Alastair Birch from Pembrokeshire County Council and Sally Jenkins from All Wales Heads of Children's Services expressed support for the Bill, emphasizing the importance of upholding children's rights and the need for clarity in legislation.
* The committee discussed the potential harm of physical punishment to children, with evidence suggesting it is demeaning and emotionally damaging.
* Concerns were raised about the reasonable punishment defense potentially undermining child protection and leading to more serious abuse.
* The Welsh Local Government Association and others stressed the importance of awareness-raising campaigns to accompany the implementation of the Bill.
* Alastair Birch highlighted the need for training and awareness among educational professionals, while Sally Jenkins emphasized the importance of preventative services and support for families.
* The committee discussed the potential impact of the Bill on resources, with Sally Jenkins stating that the costs would likely be minimal and manageable.
* The Welsh Government committed to raising awareness about the Bill, but the committee questioned whether this should be a statutory duty within the Bill itself.
* The committee concluded with a motion to exclude the public for the remainder of the meeting.
* The committee will receive additional information on school funding and in-patient child and adolescent mental health services provision in private.

* Welsh Government's commitment to awareness-raising campaigns
* Importance of training and awareness among educational professionals
* Emphasis on preventative services and support for families
* Minimal and manageable costs associated with the Bill
* Welsh Government's commitment to raising awareness about the Bill
* Questions raised about the necessity of a statutory duty for awareness-raising within the Bill
* Motion to exclude the public for the remainder of the meeting
* Additional information on school funding and mental health services to be received in private
</summary>

<summary>

    • Alastair Birch highlights the need for professional training and awareness, particularly in schools, to uphold the duty to report any significant harm.
    • Huw David stresses the Welsh Government's commitment to full involvement in the Bill's implementation, including a major awareness-raising campaign and support for parents.
    • Sally Jenkins and Alastair Birch both agree that the Bill will not criminalize parents but will provide clarity and support for families.
    • The Welsh Government has committed to raising awareness about the Bill, with Sally Jenkins suggesting that existing preventative services and universal services could be leveraged for this purpose.
    • Concerns about the costs of implementing the Bill are acknowledged, but both Jenkins and David express confidence that the costs will not be prohibitive and will not divert resources from other children's services.
</summary>
